Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves testing, extending, and applying high-accuracy theoretical methods to atmospheric chemical reactions. It consists of three tasks. Task 1 is to use theory to predict reaction rate constants and branching ratios for nitrogen-containing atmospheric species. Amines, imines, and amides are emitted from feedlots and other biogenic sources. Amines may contribute to future industrial emissions because they are key components of an industrial method for carbon dioxide capture (to reduce greenhouse gas emissions). Rate constants will be predicted for some reactions that have never been measured experimentally because the nitrogen-containing reactants are unstable. Task 2 is to further test the accuracy of Semi-Classical Transition Sate Theory (SCTST) by comparing predicted rate constants with experimental data for key atmospheric reactions. SCTST has already been shown to predict ab initio rate constants in excellent agreement with experiments for the reaction of hydroxyl radical with molecular hydrogen, without any empirical adjustments. It also predicts ab initio rate constants for chlorine atoms with methane in very good agreement with experiments. The predicted hydrogen/deuterium kinetic isotope effects (KIEs) for both reactions are as accurate as the existing experimental data. SCTST will be characterized further and then used to predict rate constant and KIEs for several additional atmospheric reactions. Task 3 is to extend the Master Equation treatment of unimolecular and recombination reactions by explicitly incorporating conservation of angular momentum. This will significantly improve on existing Master Equations, which use various untested approximations to avoid the explicit treatment. The new Master Equation will be used to generate benchmarks and can be used to predict rate constants and to analyze experimental data.

All areas of gas phase chemical kinetics will benefit from the characterization of SCTST. The benchmark Master Equation calculations will enable other researchers to test models for non-equilibrium chemical systems where collisions and chemical reactions are competitive. These include combustion, chemical manufacturing, planetary atmospheres, and astrochemistry. The results, parameterizations, source codes, and all models will be presented at scientific meetings, published in the peer-reviewed literature, and made freely available on the internet. These materials will add to the cyberinfrastructure of atmospheric chemistry. Students and postdoctoral research associates will be trained in the development and use of computational chemical kinetics methods.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
Walk outside on a summer's day and you can smell the trees, the flowers, and the freshly mown grass. These scents are from some of the many hundreds of trace atmospheric compounds released naturally and as the result of human activities. These compounds react constantly in the atmosphere to produce reaction products. But, How fast do they react? What are the products? There are so many possible reactions that most have never been measured in the laboratory and the products have never been determined, but these properties are needed if we want to predict environmental impacts. In the absence of measurements, how can we estimate the reaction rates and products and how general are our methods? These questions motivated our project.

One of the best ways to predict reaction rates and products is to use advanced theoretical methods and fast computer calculations, but these methods are undergoing constant development and computers are never fast enough. In our work, we utilized the best available methods and investigated the fundamental molecular properties that control the reaction rates and products. We made some improvements in the theoretical methods and investigated some of the fundamental properties that control reaction rates. These advances can be used in future work to predict reaction rates and products with better accuracy. In the course of our research we also predicted rates and products for some specific reactions.

The advances we made in theoretical methods are technical improvements to the computer codes used to compute the rates and products that are needed in studying atmospheres, combustion and any other non-equilibrium chemical systems. The calculations are rather difficult and these codes help to speed them up and make them more accurate. Our codes are available worldwide for free to anyone with access to a computer and the internet. 

In the course of our work, we paid particular attention to the ways that some atmospheric molecules first attract and approach each other, and then stick loosely to each other before the main chemical reaction takes place. This kind of preliminary process is very common and has an important influence on the overall reaction rate. We gained some new insights into the process during our research. Future researchers who predict reaction rates and products in atmospheres and combustion will need to take these effects into account.

During our research, we investigated specific reactions of a chemical compound produced in the atmospheric oxidation of amines (a class of nitrogen-containing compounds). Amines may be inadvertently emitted to the atmosphere if an amine-based technology is adopted for carbon capture.  The compound methaneimine is very sticky and difficult to handle in the laboratory. Its reaction rates and products have never been measured. In our calculations, we found that the reaction mechanisms are very complex and several different products are predicted. Our results can be used in future environmental impact assessments.

Theoretical methods have not yet advanced to the point where it is possible to predict the rates and products of every reaction, but we, as a community, are making progress in that direction. We are not yet able to accurately predict the reactions of the aroma compounds emitted by freshly cut flowers, but we are getting there.


 


Last Modified: 11/01/2016
Modified by: John R Barker
